elements.content: A phenoxo and end-to-end thiocyanate bridged copper­(II) coordination polymer (CP), [Cu2L2(μ-1,3-SCN)2] n , where HL is an potential tetradentate N2O2 donor Schiff base ligand, 2-(2-(ethylamino)­ethylimino)­methyl)-6-ethoxyphenol, has been synthesized and characterized. The band gap, bulk capacitance, electron lifetime, relaxation time, dielectric constant, and DC conductivity of the complex in the solid state have been studied. Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility measurement indicates the presence of weak antiferromagnetic interactions among the copper­(II) centers with J = −0.97 cm–1. The complex shows increase in conductivity when illuminated with visible light (photosensitivity ∼2.833).
elements.clean_text: A phenoxo and end-to-end thiocyanate bridged copper(II) coordination polymer (CP), [Cu2L2(μ-1,3-SCN)2] n , where HL is an potential tetradentate N2O2 donor Schiff base ligand, 2-(2-(ethylamino)ethylimino)methyl)-6-ethoxyphenol, has been synthesized and characterized. The band gap, bulk capacitance, electron lifetime, relaxation time, dielectric constant, and DC conductivity of the complex in the solid state have been studied. Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility measurement indicates the presence of weak antiferromagnetic interactions among the copper(II) centers with J = -0.97 cm-1. The complex shows increase in conductivity when illuminated with visible light (photosensitivity ~2.833).

elements.content: A MOF composed of a phenoxo bridged dinuclear copper­(II) node and an end-to-end thiocyanate linker has been synthesized and characterized. The complex shows increased conductivity when illuminated with visible light.
elements.clean_text: A MOF composed of a phenoxo bridged dinuclear copper(II) node and an end-to-end thiocyanate linker has been synthesized and characterized. The complex shows increased conductivity when illuminated with visible light.

elements.content: Metal ions are denoted as nodes and ligands as linkers in multidimensional coordination polymers (CPs). An appropriate metal–ligand complex could also be regarded as a node in place of a bare metal ion. The significance of the synthesis and characterization of these CPs lies in their promising potential applications as functional materials. Focusing on copper­(II), varieties of copper­(II)–CPs have been synthesized by various groups in order to understand the structural and chemical factors that govern the exchange coupling between paramagnetic copper­(II) centers and also to develop new functional molecular-based materials. A variety of bridging groups have been employed for the synthesis of such systems; among them the phenoxo oxygen atom of the salicylaldehyde derived Schiff bases deserves a special mention. The magnetic properties (i.e., J values of the spin coupling) of only phenoxo-bridged complexes containing Cu2O2 cores have been postulated to be dependent upon various factors, such as the coordination geometry of the copper ions, Cu–O–Cu angle, Cu–O bond lengths, Cu···Cu distances, and Addison parameter. The study of magnetic exchange mediated by this ligand is often complicated by the presence of additional bridging ligands, for example, a pseudohalide, which may bind adjacent copper­(II) centers in end-on (EO) and end-to-end (EE) modes. The EO coordination mode of a pseudohalide is associated with ferromagnetic or antiferromagnetic coupling depending on various other factors; the EE pseudohalide bridges, in general, propagate antiferromagnetic interactions, although there is also a possibility of a ferromagnetic interaction between centers when the pseudohalide binds in an end-to-end fashion. The chemistry and magnetic properties of such complexes have been the subject of several reviews. Interestingly, the dielectric properties and conductivities of such complexes are relatively less explored. For example, the semiconducting nature of a cadmium­(II) Schiff base complex having optical band gap values of 3.69 and 2.67 eV was characterized by the distribution of electronic states in both valence and conduction bands with the partial density of states. The use of such complexes in light harvesting and energy transfer is also a promising area of research.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal ions are denoted as nodes and ligands as linkers in multidimensional coordination polymers (CPs). An appropriate metal-ligand complex could also be regarded as a node in place of a bare metal ion. The significance of the synthesis and characterization of these CPs lies in their promising potential applications as functional materials. Focusing on copper(II), varieties of copper(II)-CPs have been synthesized by various groups in order to understand the structural and chemical factors that govern the exchange coupling between paramagnetic copper(II) centers and also to develop new functional molecular-based materials. A variety of bridging groups have been employed for the synthesis of such systems; among them the phenoxo oxygen atom of the salicylaldehyde derived Schiff bases deserves a special mention. The magnetic properties (i.e., J values of the spin coupling) of only phenoxo-bridged complexes containing Cu2O2 cores have been postulated to be dependent upon various factors, such as the coordination geometry of the copper ions, Cu-O-Cu angle, Cu-O bond lengths, Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances, and Addison parameter. The study of magnetic exchange mediated by this ligand is often complicated by the presence of additional bridging ligands, for example, a pseudohalide, which may bind adjacent copper(II) centers in end-on (EO) and end-to-end (EE) modes. The EO coordination mode of a pseudohalide is associated with ferromagnetic or antiferromagnetic coupling depending on various other factors; the EE pseudohalide bridges, in general, propagate antiferromagnetic interactions, although there is also a possibility of a ferromagnetic interaction between centers when the pseudohalide binds in an end-to-end fashion. The chemistry and magnetic properties of such complexes have been the subject of several reviews. Interestingly, the dielectric properties and conductivities of such complexes are relatively less explored. For example, the semiconducting nature of a cadmium(II) Schiff base complex having optical band gap values of 3.69 and 2.67 eV was characterized by the distribution of electronic states in both valence and conduction bands with the partial density of states. The use of such complexes in light harvesting and energy transfer is also a promising area of research.

elements.content: In this work, the photosensitivity of a synthesized semiconducting complex with a substantial on–off ratio has been demonstrated. Though several substances are reported to absorb visible light and generate photocurrent with a quick response, probably this is the first example of any coordination polymer constructed from a copper­(II) Schiff base complex and characterized by single crystal X-ray crystallography. Herein, we report the synthesis and X-ray characterization of a novel 2D coordination polymer having a copper­(II) Schiff base building block. The optical band gap of the complex in the solid state has been estimated experimentally. The bulk capacitance, electron lifetime, relaxation time, and dielectric constant of the complex were also explored. The value of photosensitivity is calculated to be 2.833. The complex shows increased conductivity from 3.63 × 10–5 S cm–1 to 4.13 × 10–5 S cm–1 in the presence of light.
elements.clean_text: In this work, the photosensitivity of a synthesized semiconducting complex with a substantial on-off ratio has been demonstrated. Though several substances are reported to absorb visible light and generate photocurrent with a quick response, probably this is the first example of any coordination polymer constructed from a copper(II) Schiff base complex and characterized by single crystal X-ray crystallography. Herein, we report the synthesis and X-ray characterization of a novel 2D coordination polymer having a copper(II) Schiff base building block. The optical band gap of the complex in the solid state has been estimated experimentally. The bulk capacitance, electron lifetime, relaxation time, and dielectric constant of the complex were also explored. The value of photosensitivity is calculated to be 2.833. The complex shows increased conductivity from 3.63 × 10-5 S cm-1 to 4.13 × 10-5 S cm-1 in the presence of light.

elements.content: The potential tetradentate Schiff base ligand, HL, was prepared by the condensation of N-ethyl-1,2-diaminoethane with 3-ethoxysalicylaldehyde following the literature method. The potential tetradentate Schiff base, HL, acted as a tridentate ligand and occupied three sites of the octahedral copper­(II). The remaining sites were occupied by one nitrogen and one sulfur atom from two end to end bridged thiocyanates and one phenoxo oxygen from a different ligand to form a two-dimensional coordination polymer; [Cu2L2(μ-1,3-SCN)2] n was formed. The formation of the complex is shown in .
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

The potential tetradentate Schiff base ligand, HL, was prepared by the condensation of N-ethyl-1,2-diaminoethane with 3-ethoxysalicylaldehyde following the literature method. The potential tetradentate Schiff base, HL, acted as a tridentate ligand and occupied three sites of the octahedral copper(II). The remaining sites were occupied by one nitrogen and one sulfur atom from two end to end bridged thiocyanates and one phenoxo oxygen from a different ligand to form a two-dimensional coordination polymer; [Cu2L2(μ-1,3-SCN)2] n  was formed. The formation of the complex is shown in .

elements.clean_text: 1  Synthetic route to the complex

elements.content: The complex crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pbca (). The structure determination reveals that the copper­(II) center is coordinated by one amine nitrogen atom, N(22), one imine nitrogen atom, N(19), one phenoxo oxygen atom, O(11), of the deprotonated Schiff base ligand, (L)−, and one nitrogen atom, N(1), and one sulfur atom, S(1), of two end-to-end bridging thiocyanate ligands. The sixth coordination site is occupied by a symmetry related (1 – x, −y, 1 – z) phenoxo oxygen atom, O(11)a, from a Schiff base ligand to complete its octahedral geometry. The symmetry related phenoxo oxygen, O(11)a, connects two copper­(II) to form a pseudodimer (). The pseudodimeric bridging unit Cu2O2 describes a rhombohedral plane. The rhombohedral angles of O(11)–Cu(1)–O(11)a, Cu(1)–O(11)a–Cu­(1)a, O­(11)a–Cu­(1)a–O­(11), Cu(1)a–O­(11)–Cu­(1) are 91.78(11), 88.2(1), 91.8(1), and 88.2(1)° respectively. The saturated five member ring, Cu(1)–N(22)–C(21)–C(20)–N(19) presents an envelope conformation with puckering parameters q(2) = 0.409(5) and φ = 108.0(5)°. Selected bond angles are presented in Table S1 (Supporting Information). Each copper­(II) center of the pseudodimer is connected to two neighboring copper­(II) centers of two different pseudodimers through two end-to-end thiocyanate bridges to form a two-dimensional polymeric layers along crystallographic ab plane (a). Topology analysis reveals a (4,4)-square grid topology (b) with copper­(II) occupying the nodes, where end-to-end thiocyanate connectors take part in the formation of edges.
elements.clean_text:
Description of Structure

The complex crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pbca (). The structure determination reveals that the copper(II) center is coordinated by one amine nitrogen atom, N(22), one imine nitrogen atom, N(19), one phenoxo oxygen atom, O(11), of the deprotonated Schiff base ligand, (L)-, and one nitrogen atom, N(1), and one sulfur atom, S(1), of two end-to-end bridging thiocyanate ligands. The sixth coordination site is occupied by a symmetry related (1 - x, -y, 1 - z) phenoxo oxygen atom, O(11)a, from a Schiff base ligand to complete its octahedral geometry. The symmetry related phenoxo oxygen, O(11)a, connects two copper(II) to form a pseudodimer (). The pseudodimeric bridging unit Cu2O2 describes a rhombohedral plane. The rhombohedral angles of O(11)-Cu(1)-O(11)a, Cu(1)-O(11)a-Cu(1)a, O(11)a-Cu(1)a-O(11), Cu(1)a-O(11)-Cu(1) are 91.78(11), 88.2(1), 91.8(1), and 88.2(1)° respectively. The saturated five member ring, Cu(1)-N(22)-C(21)-C(20)-N(19) presents an envelope conformation with puckering parameters q(2) = 0.409(5) and φ = 108.0(5)°. Selected bond angles are presented in Table S1 (Supporting Information). Each copper(II) center of the pseudodimer is connected to two neighboring copper(II) centers of two different pseudodimers through two end-to-end thiocyanate bridges to form a two-dimensional polymeric layers along crystallographic ab plane (a). Topology analysis reveals a (4,4)-square grid topology (b) with copper(II) occupying the nodes, where end-to-end thiocyanate connectors take part in the formation of edges.

elements.content: The complex shows intra-pseudodimeric hydrogen bonding (Figure S1, Supporting Information). The hydrogen atom H(22) attached to the nitrogen atom N(22) participates in a hydrogen bonding interaction (Table S2, Supporting Information) with the symmetry-related oxygen atom, O(13)a {symmetry transformation a = 1 – x, −y, 1 – z}. The methyl hydrogen atom, H­(11D), attached to C(112), is involved in significant C–H···π interaction (Table S3, Supporting Information) with the symmetry related (3/2 – x, −1/2 + y, z) phenyl ring C(12)–C(13)–C(14)–C(15)–C(16)–C(17). As the complex consists of centrosymmetric pseudodimeric building blocks, each interaction is duplicated and the combination of these interactions creates a 2-D supramolecular structure (Figure S2, Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text: The complex shows intra-pseudodimeric hydrogen bonding (Figure S1, Supporting Information). The hydrogen atom H(22) attached to the nitrogen atom N(22) participates in a hydrogen bonding interaction (Table S2, Supporting Information) with the symmetry-related oxygen atom, O(13)a {symmetry transformation a = 1 - x, -y, 1 - z}. The methyl hydrogen atom, H(11D), attached to C(112), is involved in significant C-H⋅⋅⋅π interaction (Table S3, Supporting Information) with the symmetry related (3/2 - x, -1/2 + y, z) phenyl ring C(12)-C(13)-C(14)-C(15)-C(16)-C(17). As the complex consists of centrosymmetric pseudodimeric building blocks, each interaction is duplicated and the combination of these interactions creates a 2-D supramolecular structure (Figure S2, Supporting Information).

elements.content:
The experimental PXRD pattern of the bulk product is in good agreement with the simulated XRD pattern from single-crystal X-ray diffraction, indicating consistency with the bulk sample ().

Hirshfeld Surfaces

The Hirshfeld surfaces of the complex, mapped over d norm, shape index, and curvedness, are illustrated in Figure S3, Supporting Information. 2D fingerprint plots are shown in , where intermolecular interactions appear as distinct spikes. Decomposition of fingerprint plots enables us to highlight particular atom pair close contacts. The proportion of C···H/H···C interactions comprises 15.6%, where as O···H/H···O interactions comprise 6.1% of the Hirshfeld surfaces for each molecule.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction

The experimental PXRD pattern of the bulk product is in good agreement with the simulated XRD pattern from single-crystal X-ray diffraction, indicating consistency with the bulk sample ().

Hirshfeld Surfaces

The Hirshfeld surfaces of the complex, mapped over d norm, shape index, and curvedness, are illustrated in Figure S3, Supporting Information. 2D fingerprint plots are shown in , where intermolecular interactions appear as distinct spikes. Decomposition of fingerprint plots enables us to highlight particular atom pair close contacts. The proportion of C⋅⋅⋅H/H⋅⋅⋅C interactions comprises 15.6%, where as O⋅⋅⋅H/H⋅⋅⋅O interactions comprise 6.1% of the Hirshfeld surfaces for each molecule.

elements.content: In the IR spectrum of the complex, a band corresponding to the azomethine (CN) stretching vibration appears at 1649 cm–1. The μ-1,3 bridging mode of the thiocyanate group is confirmed by the splitting of the absorption band corresponding to the γCN asymmetric stretching that appears at 2102 and 2075 cm–1 indicating the S- and N-coordination modes of the thiocyanate ligand, respectively. Two medium bands at 846 and 749 cm–1 may be assigned to υ­(CS). The bands in the range of 2968–2865 cm–1 are assigned to alkyl C–H bond stretching vibrations. A moderately strong, sharp peak at 3230 cm–1 may be assigned to N–H stretching vibration.
elements.clean_text:
IR and Electronic Spectra

In the IR spectrum of the complex, a band corresponding to the azomethine (CN) stretching vibration appears at 1649 cm-1. The μ-1,3 bridging mode of the thiocyanate group is confirmed by the splitting of the absorption band corresponding to the γCN asymmetric stretching that appears at 2102 and 2075 cm-1 indicating the S- and N-coordination modes of the thiocyanate ligand, respectively. Two medium bands at 846 and 749 cm-1 may be assigned to υ(CS). The bands in the range of 2968-2865 cm-1 are assigned to alkyl C-H bond stretching vibrations. A moderately strong, sharp peak at 3230 cm-1 may be assigned to N-H stretching vibration.

elements.content: The intense absorption bands at 276 and 372 nm may be assigned as intraligand π–π* and ligand to metal charge transfer (LMCT) transitions, respectively. The absorption band in the visible range at 682 nm () may be assigned as d–d transition.
elements.clean_text: The intense absorption bands at 276 and 372 nm may be assigned as intraligand π-π* and ligand to metal charge transfer (LMCT) transitions, respectively. The absorption band in the visible range at 682 nm () may be assigned as d-d transition.

elements.content:
The FESEM image of the material is presented in Figure S4 (Supporting Information), which shows that the material has an arbitrary morphology.

Mass Spectra

The electrospray ionization mass spectra (ESI-MS positive) are performed to determine molecular weight and study fragmentation pattern of possible complex adduct. The ESI-MS positive spectrum of the complex is recorded in acetonitrile solution, and the result is shown in Figure S5. In the mass spectrum of complex, the peak at m/z = 355.06 may be assigned to [CuL­(SCN)­H]+, and the peak at m/z = 298.10 corresponds to the presence of monopositive [Cu­(L)]+.
elements.clean_text:
Morphology

The FESEM image of the material is presented in Figure S4 (Supporting Information), which shows that the material has an arbitrary morphology.

Mass Spectra

The electrospray ionization mass spectra (ESI-MS positive) are performed to determine molecular weight and study fragmentation pattern of possible complex adduct. The ESI-MS positive spectrum of the complex is recorded in acetonitrile solution, and the result is shown in Figure S5. In the mass spectrum of complex, the peak at m/z = 355.06 may be assigned to [CuL(SCN)H]+, and the peak at m/z = 298.10 corresponds to the presence of monopositive [Cu(L)]+.

elements.content: The cyclic voltammogram of the complex shows an oxidation peak (E pa) at about potential 1332 mV. This can be assigned as the CuII/CuIII oxidation process. A wave (E pc) at 1265 mV is observed during the reverse scan (). The difference between the cathodic and anodic peak is 67 mV for the complex, and this suggests the reversible nature of the electron transfer processes. E 1/2 is calculated as the average of anodic (E pa) and cathodic (E pc) peak potentials. The value of E 1/2 is 1.3 V. The criteria of reversibility were checked by observing the constancy of the peak–peak separation (ΔE p = E pa – E pc) and the ratio of peak heights (i pa/i pc ∼ 1) with variation of scan rates. The redox signal remains virtually invariant under different scan rates (0.01–1.0 V s–1) in the temperature range 300–280 K. Any solvent dependent shifts and changes in the electrochemical reversibility of the redox couples are not noteworthy. Other peaks at negative potentials may be due to the reduction to lower oxidation states of copper.
elements.clean_text:
Cyclic Voltammetry

The cyclic voltammogram of the complex shows an oxidation peak (E pa) at about potential 1332 mV. This can be assigned as the CuII/CuIII oxidation process. A wave (E pc) at 1265 mV is observed during the reverse scan (). The difference between the cathodic and anodic peak is 67 mV for the complex, and this suggests the reversible nature of the electron transfer processes. E 1/2 is calculated as the average of anodic (E pa) and cathodic (E pc) peak potentials. The value of E 1/2 is 1.3 V. The criteria of reversibility were checked by observing the constancy of the peak-peak separation (ΔE p = E pa - E pc) and the ratio of peak heights (i pa/i pc ~ 1) with variation of scan rates. The redox signal remains virtually invariant under different scan rates (0.01-1.0 V s-1) in the temperature range 300-280 K. Any solvent dependent shifts and changes in the electrochemical reversibility of the redox couples are not noteworthy. Other peaks at negative potentials may be due to the reduction to lower oxidation states of copper.

elements.content: Cyclic voltammogram of the complex in acetonitrile.
elements.clean_text: 6  Cyclic voltammogram of the complex in acetonitrile.

elements.content: The absorption spectrum recorded is shown in the inset of . The spectrum shows absorption in the visible region with absorption band edge at around 420 nm. The optical band gap energy (E g) of the complex was evaluated using Tauc’s equation α h ν = A ( h ν − E g ) n where α is the absorption coefficient, E g is the band gap, h is Planck’s constant, ν is the frequency of light, and the exponent n is the electron transition process constant. A is a constant, which is taken to be 1 for the ideal case. To calculate the optical band gap energy, the value of n is taken as 1/2 (The proof is given along with Figure S6 in Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text:
Band Gap Measurement

The absorption spectrum recorded is shown in the inset of . The spectrum shows absorption in the visible region with absorption band edge at around 420 nm. The optical band gap energy (E g) of the complex was evaluated using Tauc's equation  1     α h ν = A    ( h ν -   E   g   )    n      where α is the absorption coefficient, E g is the band gap, h is Planck's constant, ν is the frequency of light, and the exponent n is the electron transition process constant. A is a constant, which is taken to be 1 for the ideal case. To calculate the optical band gap energy, the value of n is taken as 1/2 (The proof is given along with Figure S6 in Supporting Information).

elements.content: Tauc’s plot and UV–vis absorption spectra (inset).
elements.clean_text: 7  Tauc's plot and UV-vis absorption spectra (inset).

elements.content: The Tauc’s plot of the complex is given in . The optical energy band gap (E g) can be determined by extrapolating the linear region of the plot of (αhν)2 vs hν to α = 0 absorption, and the value is estimated to be about 2.95 eV. We tried to perform the calculations of the crystal lattice within the Generalized-Gradient approximation (GGA) and the Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) formulation for the exchange-correlation functional. However, the presence of strong hybridization between the Cu 3d and N 2p orbitals leads to the formation of isolated and intermediate bands in the crystal band gap. Therefore, the theoretical band gap in it cannot be determined.
elements.clean_text: The Tauc's plot of the complex is given in . The optical energy band gap (E g) can be determined by extrapolating the linear region of the plot of (αhν)2 vs hν to α = 0 absorption, and the value is estimated to be about 2.95 eV. We tried to perform the calculations of the crystal lattice within the Generalized-Gradient approximation (GGA) and the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) formulation for the exchange-correlation functional. However, the presence of strong hybridization between the Cu 3d and N 2p orbitals leads to the formation of isolated and intermediate bands in the crystal band gap. Therefore, the theoretical band gap in it cannot be determined.

elements.content: The light absorption of the material in the visible region indicates that the material has some light induced properties, and the optical band gap also suggests that there is semiconducting nature, which encourages us to further investigate the dielectric properties of the synthesized material.
elements.clean_text: The light absorption of the material in the visible region indicates that the material has some light induced properties, and the optical band gap also suggests that there is semiconducting nature, which encourages us to further investigate the dielectric properties of the synthesized material.

elements.content:
The dielectric parameters were measured on a pellet. The synthesized complex was pelletized into a disc form of diameter 7.32 mm and thickness 1.8 mm.

The complex plane impedance plot (i.e., Nyquist plot) of the sample is shown in a. The plot shows a semicircle where the bulk resistance is evaluated from the diameter of the arc.

The Bode plot of the complex is shown in b, and the electron lifetime of the material was calculated. The peak frequency is related to the inverse of the recombination lifetime or electron lifetime. Electron lifetime is determined from the following equation τ n = 1 2 π f min Here τn is the electron lifetime and f min is the peak frequency.
elements.clean_text:
Dielectric Parameters

The dielectric parameters were measured on a pellet. The synthesized complex was pelletized into a disc form of diameter 7.32 mm and thickness 1.8 mm.

The complex plane impedance plot (i.e., Nyquist plot) of the sample is shown in a. The plot shows a semicircle where the bulk resistance is evaluated from the diameter of the arc.

The Bode plot of the complex is shown in b, and the electron lifetime of the material was calculated. The peak frequency is related to the inverse of the recombination lifetime or electron lifetime. Electron lifetime is determined from the following equation  2       τ   n   =   1   2 π   f   min        Here τn is the electron lifetime and f min is the peak frequency.

elements.content: (a) Nyquist plot of the complex. (b) Bode plot of the complex.
elements.clean_text: 8  (a) Nyquist plot of the complex. (b) Bode plot of the complex.

elements.content: The impedance loss spectrum of the complex is represented in Figure S7, Supporting Information. It is used to determine the relaxation time of the complex using the following equation. τ = 1 2 π f p where τ is the relaxation time and f p is the peak frequency determined from the graph.
elements.clean_text: The impedance loss spectrum of the complex is represented in Figure S7, Supporting Information. It is used to determine the relaxation time of the complex using the following equation. 3     τ =   1   2 π   f   p        where τ is the relaxation time and f p is the peak frequency determined from the graph.

elements.content: Figure S7, ESI, gives the curve showing the variation of the capacitance (C) as a function of the frequency (log f) at constant bias potential. The room temperature capacitance of the complex shows frequency dependence at relatively low frequencies. The capacitance decreases with the increase in frequency and becomes saturated at higher frequency (Figure S8, Supporting Information). Using the value of capacitance at the saturation level, we calculated the dielectric constant of the complex using the following equation: ε r = 1 ε 0 C d A where ε0 is the permittivity of free space, εr is the dielectric constant of the synthesized material, C is the capacitance (at saturation), and d and A are the thickness and effective area of the pellet, respectively. Using the above formula, the dielectric constant (εr) of the material was estimated and given in .
elements.clean_text: Figure S7, ESI, gives the curve showing the variation of the capacitance (C) as a function of the frequency (log f) at constant bias potential. The room temperature capacitance of the complex shows frequency dependence at relatively low frequencies. The capacitance decreases with the increase in frequency and becomes saturated at higher frequency (Figure S8, Supporting Information). Using the value of capacitance at the saturation level, we calculated the dielectric constant of the complex using the following equation:  4       ε   r   =   1     ε   0       C d   A      where ε0 is the permittivity of free space, εr is the dielectric constant of the synthesized material, C is the capacitance (at saturation), and d and A are the thickness and effective area of the pellet, respectively. Using the above formula, the dielectric constant (εr) of the material was estimated and given in .

elements.content:
<table-wrap id="tbl2" position="float">

The above electrical parameters and the obtained band gap value indicate that the synthesized product has a semiconducting nature. Hence, we have further studied its light sensing behavior to check the suitability of the synthesized material for electronic applications.
elements.clean_text: The above electrical parameters and the obtained band gap value indicate that the synthesized product has a semiconducting nature. Hence, we have further studied its light sensing behavior to check the suitability of the synthesized material for electronic applications.

elements.content: The experimental χM T value at room temperature (0.86 cm3·mol–1) for the complex corresponds to the presence of two independent copper­(II) centers in the molecule (0.75 cm3·mol–1 considering g = 2) indicating an almost negligible interaction between the copper­(II) centers. However, although this value remains practically constant until around 50 K, then decreases slowly and finally drops at 11 K, reaching a value of 0.54 cm3·mol–1 at 2 K (). This decrease at very low temperatures indicates a small antiferromagnetic interaction between copper­(II) atoms. Therefore, the magnetic behavior of this complex has been simulated using : χ = N g 2 μ B 2 k T 2 e 2 J / k T 1 + 3 e 2 J / k T + TIP was derived by Bleaney and Bowers from the Hamiltonian H = −2J ij S i S j . A term considering a temperature independent paramagnetism (TIP) has also been included.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

The experimental χM T value at room temperature (0.86 cm3⋅mol-1) for the complex corresponds to the presence of two independent copper(II) centers in the molecule (0.75 cm3⋅mol-1 considering g = 2) indicating an almost negligible interaction between the copper(II) centers. However, although this value remains practically constant until around 50 K, then decreases slowly and finally drops at 11 K, reaching a value of 0.54 cm3⋅mol-1 at 2 K (). This decrease at very low temperatures indicates a small antiferromagnetic interaction between copper(II) atoms. Therefore, the magnetic behavior of this complex has been simulated using : 5     χ =   N   g   2      μ   B    2     k T     2   e    2 J  /  k T      1 + 3   e    2 J  /  k T      + TIP      was derived by Bleaney and Bowers from the Hamiltonian H = -2J  ij  S  i  S  j . A term considering a temperature independent paramagnetism (TIP) has also been included.

elements.content: Magnetic susceptibility (○) and χM T (□) versus temperature for the complex. Solid lines indicate the best fit obtained using the model indicated in the text.
elements.clean_text: 9  Magnetic susceptibility (○) and χM T (□) versus temperature for the complex. Solid lines indicate the best fit obtained using the model indicated in the text.

elements.content: The fit of the experimental data using yields the following values: g = 2.14; J = −0.97 cm–1, TIP = 2.29 × 10–5 cm3 mol–1, with σ2 = 9.71 × 10–5. In , the interactions between copper­(II) pseudodimers have not been considered despite that this type of interaction could influence notably the magnetic behavior of the complexes even through hydrogen bonds. The introduction of one term to consider the interdimer interactions using the molecular field approximation does not improve the fits showing a J value of the same order. Therefore, the interdimer coupling in this complex seems to be negligible.
elements.clean_text: The fit of the experimental data using  yields the following values: g = 2.14; J = -0.97 cm-1, TIP = 2.29 × 10-5 cm3 mol-1, with σ2 = 9.71 × 10-5. In , the interactions between copper(II) pseudodimers have not been considered despite that this type of interaction could influence notably the magnetic behavior of the complexes even through hydrogen bonds. The introduction of one term to consider the interdimer interactions using the molecular field approximation does not improve the fits showing a J value of the same order. Therefore, the interdimer coupling in this complex seems to be negligible.

elements.content: It is well-known that bis­(μ-phenoxo)-bridged dinuclear copper­(II) complexes show magnetic properties strongly dependent on structural factors. The Cu–O–Cu bridging angle, the out-of-plane shift of the phenyl rings, the Cu–O bond length, the planarity of the Cu2O2 core, and the conformation and rotation of the phenyl groups can influence the magnetic behavior of this type of complex. Although the majority of them show very strong antiferromagnetic coupling constants (up to 2J = −905 cm–1), small changes in these geometric parameters can make some of the complexes present only weak antiferromagnetic or even ferromagnetic intradimer interactions.
elements.clean_text: It is well-known that bis(μ-phenoxo)-bridged dinuclear copper(II) complexes show magnetic properties strongly dependent on structural factors. The Cu-O-Cu bridging angle, the out-of-plane shift of the phenyl rings, the Cu-O bond length, the planarity of the Cu2O2 core, and the conformation and rotation of the phenyl groups can influence the magnetic behavior of this type of complex. Although the majority of them show very strong antiferromagnetic coupling constants (up to 2J = -905 cm-1), small changes in these geometric parameters can make some of the complexes present only weak antiferromagnetic or even ferromagnetic intradimer interactions.

elements.content: The Cu–O–Cu bridging angle is one of the main parameters affecting these magnetic properties. Thompson and colleagues found that the antiferromagnetic coupling increased linearly with the increment of this angle for flat macrocyclic dinuclear copper­(II) complexes derived from 2,6-di­(R)­formylphenols. This tendency is similar to those described by Ruiz et al. for similar hydroxo- and alkoxo-bridged complexes. However, these later complexes show weaker antiferromagnetic couplings and even ferromagnetic for small Cu–O–Cu angles, while flat macrocyclic phenoxo-bridged complexes show antiferromagnetic interactions in a broad range of angles. High values of the out-of-plane angle (τ) of the phenyl rings, that is, when the phenyl groups are not in the Cu2O2 plane, favor the ferromagnetic contributions. However, this parameter has more influence in the variation of the coupling constants when the phenyl rings of the phenoxo ligands present a syn conformation. In this case, the antiferromagnetic coupling is enhanced for values of τ in the range 0–20° whereas the contrary occurs for τ > 20°. On the contrary, the out-of-plane angle does not have a very important effect if the phenyl rings show an anti conformation, although the ferromagnetic contribution is slightly favored for high values of τ. Also, the rotation of the phenyl rings influences the magnetic coupling, since the antiferromagnetic interactions increase with a perpendicular orientation of the ring with respect to the Cu2O2 core. Giapintzakis, and co-workers have also reported an important correlation of the magnetic coupling with the Cu–Ophenolate bond length. Distances lower than 1.98 Å are associated with strong antiferromagnetic coupling constants, whereas bond lengths higher than 1.98 Å can show either weak antiferromagnetic or ferromagnetic behavior. Deviations from the planarity of the Cu2O2 framework, as a function of the Cu–O–Cu–O torsion angle, have also been studied for these complexes and for the analogous hydroxo-bridged complexes. High torsion angles reduce the antiferromagnetic couplings and favor the ferromagnetic contribution. Although in copper­(II) dimers with pentacoordinate environment the magnetic exchange can be influenced by the type of connection, such as axial–equatorial, basal–basal, or basal–apical, this variable is not considered for octahedral environments.
elements.clean_text: The Cu-O-Cu bridging angle is one of the main parameters affecting these magnetic properties. Thompson and colleagues found that the antiferromagnetic coupling increased linearly with the increment of this angle for flat macrocyclic dinuclear copper(II) complexes derived from 2,6-di(R)formylphenols. This tendency is similar to those described by Ruiz et al. for similar hydroxo- and alkoxo-bridged complexes. However, these later complexes show weaker antiferromagnetic couplings and even ferromagnetic for small Cu-O-Cu angles, while flat macrocyclic phenoxo-bridged complexes show antiferromagnetic interactions in a broad range of angles. High values of the out-of-plane angle (τ) of the phenyl rings, that is, when the phenyl groups are not in the Cu2O2 plane, favor the ferromagnetic contributions. However, this parameter has more influence in the variation of the coupling constants when the phenyl rings of the phenoxo ligands present a syn conformation. In this case, the antiferromagnetic coupling is enhanced for values of τ in the range 0-20° whereas the contrary occurs for τ > 20°. On the contrary, the out-of-plane angle does not have a very important effect if the phenyl rings show an anti conformation, although the ferromagnetic contribution is slightly favored for high values of τ. Also, the rotation of the phenyl rings influences the magnetic coupling, since the antiferromagnetic interactions increase with a perpendicular orientation of the ring with respect to the Cu2O2 core. Giapintzakis, and co-workers have also reported an important correlation of the magnetic coupling with the Cu-Ophenolate bond length. Distances lower than 1.98 Å are associated with strong antiferromagnetic coupling constants, whereas bond lengths higher than 1.98 Å can show either weak antiferromagnetic or ferromagnetic behavior. Deviations from the planarity of the Cu2O2 framework, as a function of the Cu-O-Cu-O torsion angle, have also been studied for these complexes and for the analogous hydroxo-bridged complexes. High torsion angles reduce the antiferromagnetic couplings and favor the ferromagnetic contribution. Although in copper(II) dimers with pentacoordinate environment the magnetic exchange can be influenced by the type of connection, such as axial-equatorial, basal-basal, or basal-apical, this variable is not considered for octahedral environments.

elements.content: Therefore, a magneto-structural analysis can be used to explain the weak antiferromagnetic intradimer interaction (J = −0.97 cm–1) found for the complex. First of all, its Cu–O–Cu bridging angle (88.22°) is very low. Although experimental values are found in a wide range (85.5–110.4°), most of them are in the 95–110.4° range. In addition, the τ value (45.06°) is high, and the Cu–Ophenolate distances are long (2.347 Å, in average). All those values are consistent with very weak antiferromagnetic or even ferromagnetic coupling. Moreover, the anti conformation of the phenyl groups for such a high value of τ makes weaker the antiferromagnetic coupling. Nevertheless, there are other structural parameters that favor antiferromagnetic coupling and, consequently, avoid reaching the ferromagnetic interactions: the phenyl rings are almost perpendicular to the Cu2O2 core, which is completely flat (the Cu–O–Cu-O torsion angle is 0°). As a result of all these factors, the complex has very weak antiferromagnetic coupling. Nevertheless, the existence of weak ferromagnetic interaction through the phenoxo group and weak interdimer antiferromagnetic interactions through the thiocyanate ligands cannot be discarded.
elements.clean_text: Therefore, a magneto-structural analysis can be used to explain the weak antiferromagnetic intradimer interaction (J = -0.97 cm-1) found for the complex. First of all, its Cu-O-Cu bridging angle (88.22°) is very low. Although experimental values are found in a wide range (85.5-110.4°), most of them are in the 95-110.4° range. In addition, the τ value (45.06°) is high, and the Cu-Ophenolate distances are long (2.347 Å, in average). All those values are consistent with very weak antiferromagnetic or even ferromagnetic coupling. Moreover, the anti conformation of the phenyl groups for such a high value of τ makes weaker the antiferromagnetic coupling. Nevertheless, there are other structural parameters that favor antiferromagnetic coupling and, consequently, avoid reaching the ferromagnetic interactions: the phenyl rings are almost perpendicular to the Cu2O2 core, which is completely flat (the Cu-O-Cu-O torsion angle is 0°). As a result of all these factors, the complex has very weak antiferromagnetic coupling. Nevertheless, the existence of weak ferromagnetic interaction through the phenoxo group and weak interdimer antiferromagnetic interactions through the thiocyanate ligands cannot be discarded.

elements.content: The presence of strong absorbance of the synthesized complex in the visible wavelength region of light suggests that incident radiation has some influence on the charge transport properties. Furthermore, the value of optical band gap indicated the semiconducting nature of the complex. To elucidate the charge transport mechanism, electrical current was measured at a bias voltage of 2 V.
elements.clean_text:
Electrical Properties

The presence of strong absorbance of the synthesized complex in the visible wavelength region of light suggests that incident radiation has some influence on the charge transport properties. Furthermore, the value of optical band gap indicated the semiconducting nature of the complex. To elucidate the charge transport mechanism, electrical current was measured at a bias voltage of 2 V.

elements.content: The transient photocurrent response shown in is generated by the transfer of excited photoelectrons from the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO). The transient photocurrent responses of the complex are investigated for several on–off cycles of irradiation. As shown in , the current falls rapidly to the initial value when illumination turns off. Photocurrent again goes back to the maximum value as soon as the light turns on. This characteristic behavior depicts that most of the photogenerated electrons reach the ITO coated substrate to produce photocurrent under the irradiation of visible light. The result suggests that photogenerated electron–hole pairs separated efficiently for the complex. The photosensitivity of the material is 2.833, which is determined from . This figure also reveals that the material is very stable under the exposure of light. The conductivity was measured from the current–voltage characteristics graph, and it was estimated as 3.63 × 10–5 S cm–1 and 4.13 × 10–5 S cm–1 under dark and light conditions. The electrical transport parameters, which are detrimental to device performance, suggest that this material can be a promising candidate for a photoswitch.
elements.clean_text: The transient photocurrent response shown in  is generated by the transfer of excited photoelectrons from the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO). The transient photocurrent responses of the complex are investigated for several on-off cycles of irradiation. As shown in , the current falls rapidly to the initial value when illumination turns off. Photocurrent again goes back to the maximum value as soon as the light turns on. This characteristic behavior depicts that most of the photogenerated electrons reach the ITO coated substrate to produce photocurrent under the irradiation of visible light. The result suggests that photogenerated electron-hole pairs separated efficiently for the complex. The photosensitivity of the material is 2.833, which is determined from . This figure also reveals that the material is very stable under the exposure of light. The conductivity was measured from the current-voltage characteristics graph, and it was estimated as 3.63 × 10-5 S cm-1 and 4.13 × 10-5 S cm-1 under dark and light conditions. The electrical transport parameters, which are detrimental to device performance, suggest that this material can be a promising candidate for a photoswitch.

elements.content: Transient photocurrent response of the complex.
elements.clean_text: 10  Transient photocurrent response of the complex.

elements.content: In conclusion, we report the synthesis and X-ray characterization of a novel coordination polymer based on a N2O2 donor potential tetradentate Schiff base ligand and μ-1,3-thiocyanates as linkers. The copper­(II) CP exhibits electrical conductivity that has been rationalized by band gap measurement. The phenoxo bridged complex has very weak antiferromagnetic coupling. Several dielectric parameters like bulk capacitance, electron lifetime, relaxation time, and dielectric constant of the complex in the solid state have also been studied. On irradiation with visible light, there is a considerable increase in the conductivity of the complex. The photosensitivity of the material is 2.833, and the material is very stable under the exposure to light, which suggests that it can be used as a photoswitch.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, we report the synthesis and X-ray characterization of a novel coordination polymer based on a N2O2 donor potential tetradentate Schiff base ligand and μ-1,3-thiocyanates as linkers. The copper(II) CP exhibits electrical conductivity that has been rationalized by band gap measurement. The phenoxo bridged complex has very weak antiferromagnetic coupling. Several dielectric parameters like bulk capacitance, electron lifetime, relaxation time, and dielectric constant of the complex in the solid state have also been studied. On irradiation with visible light, there is a considerable increase in the conductivity of the complex. The photosensitivity of the material is 2.833, and the material is very stable under the exposure to light, which suggests that it can be used as a photoswitch.

cln_elements.content:
In this work, the photosensitivity of a synthesized semiconducting complex with a substantial on–off ratio has been demonstrated. Though several substances are reported to absorb visible light and generate photocurrent with a quick response, probably this is the first example of any coordination polymer constructed from a copper­(II) Schiff base complex and characterized by single crystal X-ray crystallography. Herein, we report the synthesis and X-ray characterization of a novel 2D coordination polymer having a copper­(II) Schiff base building block. The optical band gap of the complex in the solid state has been estimated experimentally. The bulk capacitance, electron lifetime, relaxation time, and dielectric constant of the complex were also explored. The value of photosensitivity is calculated to be 2.833. The complex shows increased conductivity from 3.63 × 10–5 S cm–1 to 4.13 × 10–5 S cm–1 in the presence of light.

The Tauc’s plot of the complex is given in . The optical energy band gap (E g) can be determined by extrapolating the linear region of the plot of (αhν)2 vs hν to α = 0 absorption, and the value is estimated to be about 2.95 eV. We tried to perform the calculations of the crystal lattice within the Generalized-Gradient approximation (GGA) and the Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) formulation for the exchange-correlation functional. However, the presence of strong hybridization between the Cu 3d and N 2p orbitals leads to the formation of isolated and intermediate bands in the crystal band gap. Therefore, the theoretical band gap in it cannot be determined.

Magnetic Properties

The experimental χM T value at room temperature (0.86 cm3·mol–1) for the complex corresponds to the presence of two independent copper­(II) centers in the molecule (0.75 cm3·mol–1 considering g = 2) indicating an almost negligible interaction between the copper­(II) centers. However, although this value remains practically constant until around 50 K, then decreases slowly and finally drops at 11 K, reaching a value of 0.54 cm3·mol–1 at 2 K (). This decrease at very low temperatures indicates a small antiferromagnetic interaction between copper­(II) atoms. Therefore, the magnetic behavior of this complex has been simulated using : χ = N g 2 μ B 2 k T 2 e 2 J / k T 1 + 3 e 2 J / k T + TIP was derived by Bleaney and Bowers from the Hamiltonian H = −2J ij S i S j . A term considering a temperature independent paramagnetism (TIP) has also been included.

In this work, the photosensitivity of a synthesized semiconducting complex with a substantial on-off ratio has been demonstrated. Though several substances are reported to absorb visible light and generate photocurrent with a quick response, probably this is the first example of any coordination polymer constructed from a copper(II) Schiff base complex and characterized by single crystal X-ray crystallography. Herein, we report the synthesis and X-ray characterization of a novel 2D coordination polymer having a copper(II) Schiff base building block. The optical band gap of the complex in the solid state has been estimated experimentally. The bulk capacitance, electron lifetime, relaxation time, and dielectric constant of the complex were also explored. The value of photosensitivity is calculated to be 2.833. The complex shows increased conductivity from 3.63 × 10-5 S cm-1 to 4.13 × 10-5 S cm-1 in the presence of light.

The Tauc's plot of the complex is given in . The optical energy band gap (E g) can be determined by extrapolating the linear region of the plot of (αhν)2 vs hν to α = 0 absorption, and the value is estimated to be about 2.95 eV. We tried to perform the calculations of the crystal lattice within the Generalized-Gradient approximation (GGA) and the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) formulation for the exchange-correlation functional. However, the presence of strong hybridization between the Cu 3d and N 2p orbitals leads to the formation of isolated and intermediate bands in the crystal band gap. Therefore, the theoretical band gap in it cannot be determined.

Magnetic Properties

The experimental χM T value at room temperature (0.86 cm3⋅mol-1) for the complex corresponds to the presence of two independent copper(II) centers in the molecule (0.75 cm3⋅mol-1 considering g = 2) indicating an almost negligible interaction between the copper(II) centers. However, although this value remains practically constant until around 50 K, then decreases slowly and finally drops at 11 K, reaching a value of 0.54 cm3⋅mol-1 at 2 K (). This decrease at very low temperatures indicates a small antiferromagnetic interaction between copper(II) atoms. Therefore, the magnetic behavior of this complex has been simulated using : 5     χ =   N   g   2      μ   B    2     k T     2   e    2 J  /  k T      1 + 3   e    2 J  /  k T      + TIP      was derived by Bleaney and Bowers from the Hamiltonian H = -2J  ij  S  i  S  j . A term considering a temperature independent paramagnetism (TIP) has also been included.

metadata.title:
A Semiconducting
Copper(II) Coordination Polymer with
(4,4) Square Grid Topology: Synthesis, Characterization, and Application
in the Formation of a Photoswitch
